_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: 1910.119 Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ull Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) in February/March 2013 to assess potential areas to improve safety at the Facility. A PHA on the modified Fractionation process was later completed in August 2103 and a PHA on the Tank Farm Reconfiguration was completed in August 2014.

A new PSM Policy and associated procedures plan to be issued and implemented at the Riverside Fractionation Plant in 2015.

The Riverside Fractionation Plant, located near the town of Geismar in Ascension Parish, Louisiana utilizes more than the threshold quantity of a regulated flammable substance (10,000 pounds) in the processing of natural gas, where natural gas liquids (NGL) are fractionated into butanes and natural gasoline products. Therefore, this Facility is subject to the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements codified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 (40 CFR 68) administered by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).

The Riverside Plant is also subject to Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and public receptors are located within the worst-case release scenario for the plant. Therefore, the Riverside Plant is subject to Program 3 requirements as stated in 40 CFR 68.10. OSHA's PSM standard closely parallels requirements outlined in USEPA's RMP Rule. All elements required by USEPA's 40 CFR 68 - Program 3 Prevention Program are also required by OSHA's PSM.

The Riverside Plant has not had an accidental release of a regulated substance where exposure to the substance, its reaction products, overpressure generated by an explosion involving the substance, or radiant heat generated by a fire involving the substance led to any off-site death, injury, or response or restoration activities for an exposure of an environmental receptor within the last five (5) years.

The Riverside Plant employs 24 full-time employees on-site who will ensure the proper operation and maintenance of the Facility.

EnLink Processing Services, LLC (EnLink), formerly Crosstex Energy, last submitted a full RMP 5-year update to the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) in January 2012 for the Riverside Fractionation Plant. The current RMP includes process updates associated with the change from Crosstex Energy to EnLink, as well as process updates of a change to the facility th

at required a revised process hazard analysis. The Riverside Fractionation Plant previously fractionated NGLs into ethanes, propanes, butanes and natural gasoline products and has changed its process in November 2014 into solely fractionating NGLs into butanes and natural gasoline products.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

The Riverside Fractionation Plant maintains a policy of safe NGL fractionation operations, reducing to the greatest extent possible hazards associated with the extraction processes, and reducing subsequent risk to the surrounding community, employees, and the environment.

The Riverside Plant has procedures in place, including both on-site activities and coordination with off-site responders that are to be followed in the event of a flammable material release.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Riverside Fractionation Plant separates mixed natural gas liquids (NGLs) into commercial products such as isobutane, normal butane and natural gasoline. NGL is received as raw feed via pipeline. The raw feed NGLs are fractionated into butanes and natural gasoline products. N-butane and isobutane are extracted from the raw feed through further fractionation and are stored in pressurized storage tanks prior to being shipped for commercial distribution via pipelines, marine vessels, tank trucks, and/or railcars.

At the end of the fractionation process, the heaviest portion of NGLs (e.g., pentanes and heavier) results in production of natural gasoline. Natural gasoline is also received by tank trucks as a finished product for future distribution in commerce. All of natural gasoline (produced at the Plant and delivered from other sources) is pumped into one of three floating roof storage tanks. The gasoline is shipped to commercial
markets by marine vessel or tank truck. 

The Riverside Fractionation Plant processing has been evaluated for RMP applicability. No RMP-regulated toxic substances a

re stored at the Facility above RMP threshold quantities. Butane and isobutane are RMP regulated flammables stored above RMP threshold quantities. NGL is also a regulated flammable processed above RMP threshold quantities. The following list presents the storage capacities and largest tanks/vessels for all RMP-regulated chemicals over threshold planning quantities at the Facility:

Isobutane: Total storage capacity (2,422,764 lbs); Largest tank (1,735,437 lbs)
Butane: Total storage capacity (9,150,158 lbs); Largest tank (1,803,188 lbs)
NGL: Total storage capacity (991,392 lbs); Largest vessel (177,803 lbs)

Natural gasoline has a National Fire Protection Agency (NFPA) flammability rating of 3, which makes this substance exempt from the RMP threshold determination. The Facility also stores used oil, heating oil and light crude oil, all of which are not RMP-regulated.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Riverside Fractionation Plant maintains a consistent accidental release prevention program to eliminate or minimize releases of NGL and natural gas condensate. As previously indicated, the Prevention Program required under 40 CFR 68 is identical to the Prevention Program required under OSHA's PSM 29 CFR 1910.119. The Riverside Fractionation Plant's Prevention Program 3 elements, as required under 40 CFR 68 Subpart D, are included in the facility's PSM Plan, which is kept on-site as a separate document. Required elements include: 

¿	Employee Participation,
¿	Process Safety Information,
¿	Process Hazard Analysis,
¿	Operating Procedures,
¿	Training,
¿	Contractors,
¿	Pre-startup Review,
¿	Mechanical Integrity,
¿	Hot Work Permits,
¿	Management of Change,
¿	Incident Investigation, and
¿	Compliance Audits.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Riverside Fractionation Plant has had no accidental releases of NGL, isobutane or n-butane that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage o
